exercise: numbers = [1, 2, 3]. Use the append() method to add the number 4 to the list. Print the list.
fruits = ['apple', 'banana']. Use append() to add 'orange' to the list. Print the updated list.
colors = []. Use append() three times to add 'red', 'green', and 'blue' to the empty list. Print the list after each append.
animals = ['dog', 'cat']. Use append() to add 'fish' to the list. Print the list.
numbers = [10, 20, 30]. Use append() to add the sum of all elements in the list to the end of the list. Print the updated list.
letters = ['a', 'b', 'c']. Store the result of the append() method in a variable named result when adding 'd'. Print both the list and the value of result.
my_list = [1, 2, 3]. Use append() to add the string 'four' to the list. Print the updated list.
prices = [9.99, 19.99, 29.99]. Use append() to add the average of these prices to the list. Print the updated list.
names = ['Alice', 'Bob']. Use append() to add a nested list ['Charlie', 'David'] to the names list. Print the result.
data = [True, False]. Use append() to add the result of True and False (using and operator) to the list. Print the updated list.
measurements = [10, 20, 30]. Use append() to add the maximum value multiplied by 2 to the list. Print the result.
words = ['hello', 'world']. Use append() to add the concatenation of all words in the list to the end of the list. Print the result.
values = [5, 10, 15]. Create a new list containing the squares of these values. Then append this new list to the original list. Print the result.
numbers = [1, 2, 3]. Make a copy of this list, append 4 to the copy, and then append the copy to the original list. Print the result.
matrix = [[1, 2], [3, 4]]. Use append() to add a new row [5, 6] to the matrix. Print the updated matrix.
nested = [1, [2, 3], 4]. Use append() to add the number 5 to the inner list (not the outer list). Print the result.
coordinates = [(1, 2), (3, 4)]. Use append() to add the tuple (5, 6) to the list. Print the updated list.
numbers = [1, 2, 3]. Create a copy of this list and modify it by appending 4. Print both lists to confirm only the copy was modified.
data = [[1], [2], [3]]. Create a list of the lengths of each inner list, then append this list to data. Print the result.
records = [{'name': 'Alice', 'age': 25}]. Create a new dictionary for Bob who is 30, and append it to records. Print the updated list.
